@metadata.goal: The student can partition shapes into equal parts

steps.dialogue: Partition this bar into fourths. Then write the fraction that represents one part.

prompt.text: Divide the bar and write the unit fraction

step.dialogue: Check your work. Make sure you have four equal parts and the correct fraction.

events.name: sequential_division
events.description: Bar shows sequential division strategy with three vertical lines appearing to create four equal sections

step.dialogue: [event:sequential_division]Let's think about this together. Fourths means 4 equal parts. Each part is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction] of the whole, written as [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction].

events.name: divide_into_fourths
events.description: Animated demonstration showing bar being divided into 4 equal sections with measurement lines confirming equal width

events.name: highlight_one_section
events.description: One section pulses with label '1 part' while annotation shows '4 equal parts total'

events.name: show_fraction_notation
events.description: Fraction 1/4 appears with arrows pointing from highlighted section to numerator 1 and from total sections to denominator 4

step.dialogue: [event:divide_into_fourths][event:highlight_one_section][event:show_fraction_notation]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. First, we divide the bar into 4 equal parts - that's fourths. Each part is the same size. One of these parts is 1 out of 4, which we write as [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. The 1 on top shows one part, and the 4 on bottom shows four total parts. That's how unit fractions work - the numerator is always 1.

on_correct.dialogue: You divided the bar into fourths and wrote the unit fraction.

@metadata.goal: The student can partition shapes into equal parts

steps.dialogue: Divide this bar into thirds. Then write the number that shows how many equal parts make the whole.

prompt.text: Divide the bar into thirds and write the denominator

step.dialogue: Check your work. Make sure the bar has three equal parts.

events.name: sequential_division_strategy
events.description: Sequential division strategy shown - bar divides into 3 equal sections with each section highlighting briefly

events.name: pulse
events.description: Denominator input field pulses to draw attention to the connection

step.dialogue: [event:sequential_division_strategy][event:pulse]Let's think about this together. Thirds means three equal parts. Check that each section is the same size, and the denominator matches.

events.name: animated_division_into_thirds
events.description: Animated demonstration showing two cut lines appearing to divide bar into 3 equal sections, with measurement lines confirming equal width

events.name: counting_overlay
events.description: Numbers 1, 2, 3 appear sequentially over each section as they are counted

events.name: auto_fill_3
events.description: The number 3 appears in the denominator input field with a brief glow

step.dialogue: [event:animated_division_into_thirds][event:counting_overlay][event:auto_fill_3]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. To divide into thirds, we need three equal parts. Watch as I cut the bar into three sections of the same size. Now count them: one, two, three equal parts. That's why the denominator is 3 - it shows how many equal parts make the whole. See how thirds work - 3 equal parts make one whole.

on_correct.dialogue: You divided the bar into thirds and connected it to the denominator.
